context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Number 80-1464, Watt, the Secretary of Interior against the Energy Action Educational Foundation will be announced by Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: This case concerns the bidding systems the Secretary of the Interior must use in the leasing by auction of oil and gas tracts on the Outer Continental Shelf.

context.text: Prior to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act Amendments of 1978, the Secretary almost always auctioned leases on the Outer Continental Shelf on the basis of a fixed royalty with the bidding on the amount of an initial cash bonus to be paid when the lease was awarded.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Section 106 of Public Law Number 92-129 enacted in 1971 prohibits employment discrimination against United States citizens on military basis overseas unless permitted by “treaty”.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The question in this case is whether the word treaty is used in the 1971 Act includes executive agreements concluded by the President with the host country or whether instead it is limited to those international agreements entered into by the President when the advice and consent of the Senate pursuant to Article II of the United States Constitution.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Our examination of the legislative history, the meaning of the language Congress used and other applicable canons of construction leads us to a different conclusion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In an opinion filed today with the clerk, we hold that the word treaty in Section 106 embraces executive agreements such as we're involved in this case as well as Article II treaties.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Justice Rehnquist.
